I didn’t realize it at first. I just thought it was a weird package — a small box with no return address, delivered to my front door in the middle of a rainy Tuesday. I opened it, and the room was suddenly covered in neon pink glitter. It was everywhere: on the floor, in my hair, even in the crevices of my keyboard. I laughed at first, thinking it was some kind of prank from a friend. But when I saw the note inside — *“You’re not as anonymous as you think”* — I started to feel a chill.

I’d been active on 4chan for years, mostly just browsing and occasionally posting under a throwaway username. I never gave out any real info. I didn’t think anyone would care enough to track me down. But apparently, someone had.

Looking back, I should’ve known something was off. A few weeks before the glitter bomb, I noticed some strange comments on a forum post I made. They weren’t from people I knew, and they mentioned details I’d never shared publicly — my city, my age, even the name of the coffee shop I frequented. It wasn’t a big secret, but it was enough to make me uneasy. I brushed it off as a coincidence.

But the glitter bomb was no coincidence.

That’s when it hit me: the data I thought was buried in the digital ether had already been pulled together, pieced together by someone who didn’t just want to troll me — they wanted to find me.

I started digging, trying to figure out how they did it. Turns out, it wasn’t that hard. A combination of IP logs, location data from a forgotten social media check-in, and a couple of forum posts with subtle clues had been enough. It wasn’t a sophisticated hack. It was just a matter of connecting the dots.

After that, I started seeing the internet differently. I realized how easy it is for your life to be mapped out — not by some shadowy government agency or hacker collective, but by someone with a little patience and a lot of curiosity. I learned to be more careful, to think twice before posting anything, even in the most anonymous corners of the web.

But the glitter bomb wasn’t just a lesson. It was a moment of reckoning. It wasn’t scary in the way you’d expect — it was more like waking up and realizing you’ve been sleepwalking through your own privacy.

---

Later that day, I posted a vague comment on 4chan about it. Just something like, “Got a glitter bomb at my door. No idea who sent it.” And then someone replied: “You’re not as anonymous as you think.”

I read it and felt a little chill, but I didn’t think much of it. I mean, it was probably just some random kid messing around. I didn’t give it another thought. I didn’t want to.

Looking back, I don’t even know how they found me. I never gave out my address. I never used my real name. But maybe I left a trail somewhere — a forum comment with a city name, a check-in on a now-defunct app, a username that was too consistent. I don’t know. I didn’t look into it. I just changed my password on a few sites and moved on.

The glitter was gone in a day. The feeling that someone had known where I lived? It lingered, but not in a way that stopped me from using the internet. It was just one of those little things that happens — like realizing your ex still has your Netflix password. Not a big deal. Just a little weird.
